qas.question: What is the practive of coprophagia behaviours?

answers.text: eating specialised faeces in order to re-digest food

qas.question: Why do some animals pass food through their gut twice?
What happens with these soft feacal pellets?

context: Other animals, such as rabbits and rodents, practise coprophagia behaviours - <a0_0>eating specialised faeces in order to re-digest food<a0_0/>, especially in the case of roughage. Capybara, rabbits, hamsters and other related species do not have a complex digestive system as do, for example, ruminants. Instead they <a1_0>extract more nutrition<a1_0/> from grass by giving their food a second pass through the gut. Soft faecal pellets of partially digested food are <a2_0>excreted and generally consumed immediately<a2_0/>. They also produce normal droppings, which are <a3_0>not eaten<a3_0/>.
